content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This is a low-power view of a fragmented tissue specimen, likely a lymph node dissection from a colorectal cancer resection. The majority of the tissue is adipose tissue (fat), interspersed with multiple fragments of tissue. There are several small, dense, basophilic (dark purple) nodules scattered throughout, which are highly suggestive of lymph nodes. On the left, there is a larger piece of tissue marked with black ink, which could be part of the primary tumor or a specific margin.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to identify all lymph nodes and examine them for metastatic cancer. The area highlighted by the green box contains a distinct, small, basophilic nodule embedded in fat. This is the characteristic appearance of a lymph node at low magnification. I need to zoom in to assess its architecture and cellular detail to determine if it is benign (reactive) or malignant (containing metastatic tumor). This is a routine step in the systematic evaluation of a cancer resection specimen. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a portion of a lymph node that is heavily infiltrated by tumor. The normal lymphoid tissue is largely replaced by clusters and irregular glands of malignant cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with prominent eosinophilic cytoplasm, which are features of adenocarcinoma. There is also a large area of eosinophilic, cracked material at the top of the image, which is consistent with tumor necrosis. The tissue to the left is mature adipose tissue. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma, showing extensive replacement of the nodal parenchyma and associated necrosis.
